column5: How has your learning experience been from the course?
column6: What is your opinion on professor's take on the course? (eg. teaching style, flexibility with deadlines, etc. )
column7: How were assessments/evaluations done for the course? (Minors/Majors/Projects/Assignments)
column8:
Was there a significant impact of this course in your career plans? (Internships, projects, etc.) Or
Any expectations from the course which you believed will help your career plans
column9: On a scale of 1-5, would you recommend anyone with genuine interest in that particular topic to take up this course? (In terms of expectation and outcome from the course)

column8: I am doing a summer inter project on this topic

column6: Very good course, too many topics to cover, can be hectic, but it is enjoyable so it is good

column5: Great teaching style. Perfect course pace, good content. Easy but grunt work assignments.
column6: Deadlines were okayish in rigidity. Good teaching style. Does not rush and entertains doubts very well.
column7: Assignments were moderate in difficulty and moderate in grading.
column8: Not a very ‘Must do course’ but definitely nice to learn new topics

column5: Prof. Rahul Garg is a very sweet professor who tries to change topics only once everyone seems to have understood it. He is very resourceful too.
column6: Quite flexible deadlines and the teaching style is mentioned above.
column7: Minors was graded with sir's rubrics so it was quite fair. The rest we'll get to know once the semester ends.
column8: I got a certain amount of interest towards academia/research which I used to loathe earlier. I think I'll consider continuing under Prof. Garg.

column5: Great experience. Got hands on experience with fMRI scanning. A lot of critical thinking involved in paper as well as in class. Pre minor was mostly cognitive science dominated, post minor was statistics - so serves both the tastes. It is not a ML course - we learn about estimation theory to estimate model parameters but we do not train models or build such. It is more about stats than ML.
column6: Sir has a genuine interest in teaching the course, making it enjoyable for students as well. He is quite considerate with deadlines and flexible too about it. All necessary resources and help is provided from his side.
column7: Pre minor we got tons of home works on ted ed videos on exceptional brain discoveries, but later assignments took their place. 10% marks reduction for every late submission. Gradescope submissions. There is a mid term presentation - with prof and peer review; marks assigned based on ur literature review and action plan for the project. Exams are doable - involves design choice questions and theory. And mathematics for estimation. Signal processing basics like LTI and all are expected for the course. And MTL106 as well. Evaluations are fair.
column8: The project I am doing for the course has an impact on the CV. It does interest people into learning more about me. Possibly might have an impact if u r looking towards a neuroscience career. Cs people do find a place here in building statistical models for understanding brain connectivity and functioning.
